div.div: 2. str getLongUrl(tinyUrl) --> internal and works with redirection
3. Ability to delete old or unused url
4. Hash code length should be 10 chars or so

div.h1: Back of the envelop Calculations( dnt waste lot of time on this)
div.div: 1. Total users of the site - 500 M
6. Rps = 50*150/24*60*60 --> number won't add much value as we always face spike and low periods in our systemÂ
6. Will do further calculations in some time (TODO)

switch.text: Back of the envelop Calculations( dnt waste lot of t...

div.div: 2. Server keeps a hash map ofÂ Â

ID(generated from URL)| URL| Tiny URL
ID (generated from tinyURL)| ID generated from URL
server generates SHA ID from long URL | longURL| tinyURL generated from server's hash function
server gets info of the long URL id , retreives long url and does redirection with status as 302 and longURL in the location

div.div: ID1 | long url| tiny url | timestamp --> for future cleanup
Key Value stores such as DynamoDB, Cassandra can work best--> why ? highly available, scalability is easy just add more nodes
--> I'll come on issues with DB on scale and sharding in some time (TODO)

div.div: 1. primary key of the table can be SHA256 --> any server can generate --> hence stateless
2. tinyURL id can be generated by 1 server --> but it can result in single point of failure
3. But how to generate the tiny URL ?
--> depending on the length of uuid 62^nÂ id generation are possible
4. Hash collision --> append user id and recompute or append timestamp and then recompute --> you can save the extra string in the DB

div.div: 1. HTTP status 301 implies browser will cache the long url for the tiny url
2. HTTP status 302 implies server will do the redirection always --> better right, gives more control to the server

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 248px; height: 1px; padding-top: 833px; margin-left: 1652px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
multiple shards how to know where data is stored?
1. Range based sharding
2. Hash based sharding --> use consistent hashing
3. Bloom Filters as a concept to detect if a key exists in a shard

switch.text: multiple shards how to know where data is...

a.text: Viewer does not support full SVG 1.1
